Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hydrodynamic Simulations of the Local Group
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Local Group of Galaxies (including the Milky Way, Andromeda, and their satellite galaxies) contains the best-studied galaxies in the Universe. These objects can act as a Rosetta Stone for our understanding of galaxy formation and the nature of Dark Matter, a substance that makes up more than 80% of the mass in the Universe. Dark Matter remains mysterious and is yet undetected through direct methods.

The two investigators will develop highly advanced supercomputer simulations of the gravitational pull of members of the Local Group, beginning from the very early Universe and running the simulation to the present day. These simulations will be compared to state-of-the-art observations to further our understanding of the nature of Dark Matter and how galaxies form. The investigators will work closely with graduate students, helping to train them to be independent researchers with valuable computational skills.

The investigators will also engage in an array of broader impact and outreach efforts associated with the proposal. One will help instruct and supervise a summer program that provides hands-on research experiences for high school students and fosters an interest in STEM fields to a student group of 50% women and 30% under-represented minorities. The other investigator will work to provide underrepresented students with resources, skills, and connections that will allow them to pursue and complete graduate degrees in Physics and Astronomy. Additionally, the investigators will provide their simulated galaxy catalogs and mock observations to the public via a web-based interface that is already operational for the investigators' past projects.

The research will consist of a total of seven high-resolution simulations of Local-Group like volumes, providing excellent statistics. The novel aspects of the proposed work will include: (1) sophisticated implementations of star-formation and feedback physics using a new code that relies on meshless hydrodynamic solvers, and (2) the first study of a simulated Local Group that has high enough resolution, realistic enough physics modules, and a large enough simulated volume to capture the formation of dwarf satellites, isolated dwarfs, and Milky Way/Andromeda analogs in the same simulation. The investigators will compare the star formation histories, gas content, morphologies, kinematics, and metallicities of the simulated galaxies to observations. A key goal will be to discern whether cosmic reionization imprints characteristic signatures in observable properties of dwarf galaxies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Local Group of galaxies is a crucial testing ground for theories of cosmology and galaxy formation. This project has advanced our understanding of tensions between theory and observations on multiple fronts.

Intellectual Merit:

One focus of the project was simulating, at very high resolution, Local Group analogs in the standard Cold Dark Matter (CDM) model, including detailed physics galaxy formation modeling. This work has demonstrated that many of the challenges to the CDM model -- including the number of expected low-mass galaxies and their distribution around the Milky Way and the Andromeda galaxy -- are less severe than originally thought. At the same time, this work pointed to new issues that are indicative of either difficulties in current numerical modeling or of fundamental issues within the underlying model. These issues include the abundance of very dense, baryon-dominated galaxies and the masses of the puniest dark matter halos expected to host galaxies (which may only consist of a few hundred stars).

A second focus of this project was simulating isolated dwarf galaxies with different assumptions about the nature of dark matter. In particular, models in which dark matter has higher velocities in the early universe ("warm dark matter", WDM), scatters off of itself ("self-interacting dark matter", SIDM), or both (SIWDM) allow for rich phenomenology and can provide alternate explanations for various Local Group puzzles. This work demonstrated that these models can also reproduce observations within the Local Group, and some systems -- very faint galaxies with very large sizes -- are more readily explained in SIDM or SIWDM than in CDM.

Finally, an important outcome of this project was the development of a hybrid method for simulating the distribution of matter around Local Group galaxies: while previous work either included only the gravitational interaction of matter or, at significantly lower resolution, the full hydrodynamical interactions of normal matter as well, we developed a method that has the speed of dark matter only simulations but that accurately reproduces many properties of the much more expensive full-physics simulations. This will provide a valuable tool moving forward.

Broader Impacts:

The PI worked on several directions related to broader impacts. These included:

-- helping to successfully advocate for the elimination of the use of the Physics GRE, which is a significant financial burden and has multipe demonstrated biases, for graduate admissions at UT Austin

-- developing and participating in teacher development workshops for secondary school teachers in Texas. These workshops, hosted at McDonald Observatory, provide a way to disseminate scientific knowledge very broadly and to expose a wide segment of the population to exciting topics in phyics and astronomy

-- speaking at many events for the public, including multiple talks at "Astronomy on Tap" (attended by 200-400 people each time)

-- serving as the guest editor of AASWOMEN, the American Astronomical Society's newsletter for women in Astronomy

-- serving as the research mentor for multiple students of color.
